prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3151 -- Kinematic Tuning
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe kinematic tracers and continuum over the inner 1 pc of the pre-protocluster BGPSv2_G015.503-00.420 (BGPS catalog number 3151).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select parameters based on existing single-dish observations and the expected properties of the cores and small-scale fragmentation inside of the clump. This science goal is for kinematic tracers HCO+/HCN and a line clean continuum in LSB. A 7-point filled-hexagon mosaic is used to effeciently double the FOV (0.48 HPBW spacing) to cover the inner 1 pc of the clump, an area shown to have a high column density from a 70 um absorption feature. The clump has structure on th scale of 1' but we do not require the ACA because the science objective is to observe the embedded cores, and at 3.6 kpc a 0.1 pc core is 5.5", less than the 9.7" maximum angular scale of the 12m array. For the spectral line observations, we use the HCO+ 3-2 peak intensity measured on the HHT (30" beam) at 0.71 K and select a desired per channel sensitivity to be one tenth the peak. We select 0.3 km/s spectral resolution to span at least 3-4 channels across a > 1 km/s linewidth high-mass core. C32-1 configuration and ~1.4" resolution is used to span at least 3-4 resolution elements across a 0.1 pc (5.5") core and meet sensitivity goals. We estimate the continuum flux density at 270 GHz from 40" apertures centered on the peak in the BGPS (Bolocam) maps, uniformly distributing the flux, and calculating the flux density within our synthesized beam. Because we expect the clump to be fragmented on small scales, this is a conservative estimate. However, the sensitivity requirements are set by the spectral line observations, so this is of secondary concern. Through local access on the HHT, the PI can map the entire region for zero spacing data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4029 -- Kinematic Tuning
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe kinematic tracers and continuum over the inner 1 pc of the pre-protocluster BGPSv2_G024.051-00.215 (BGPS catalog number 4029).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(Note that this is the same wording as ScienceGoal "3151 -- Kinematic Tuning" but with subsituted quantities.)
We select parameters based on existing single-dish observations and the expected properties of the cores and small-scale fragmentation inside of the clump. This science goal is for kinematic tracers HCO+/HCN and a line clean continuum in LSB. A 7-point filled-hexagon mosaic is used to effeciently double the FOV (0.48 HPBW spacing) to cover the inner 1 pc of the clump, an area shown to have a high column density from a 70 um absorption feature. The clump has structure on th scale of 1' but we do not require the ACA because the science objective is to observe the embedded cores, and at 4.5 kpc a 0.1 pc core is 4.5", less than the 9.8" maximum angular scale of the 12m array. For the spectral line observations, we use the HCO+ 3-2 peak intensity measured on the HHT (30" beam) at 0.71 K and select a desired per channel sensitivity to be one tenth the peak. We select 0.3 km/s spectral resolution to span at least 3-4 channels across a > 1 km/s linewidth high-mass core. C32-1 configuration and ~1.4" resolution is used to span at least 3-4 resolution elements across a 0.1 pc (4.5") core and meet sensitivity goals. We estimate the continuum flux density at 270 GHz from 40" apertures centered on the peak in the BGPS (Bolocam) maps, uniformly distributing the flux, and calculating the flux density within our synthesized beam. Because we expect the clump to be fragmented on small scales, this is a conservative estimate. However, the sensitivity requirements are set by the spectral line observations, so this is of secondary concern. Through local access on the HHT, the PI can map the entire region for zero spacing data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3151 -- Deuteration Tuning
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe deuterated species (N2D+, DCO+, DCN) as tracers of the coldest, densest cores and outflow tracers (CO, SiO) over the inner 1 pc of the pre-protocluster BGPSv2_G015.503-00.420 (BGPS catalog number 3151).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We select parameters based on existing single-dish observations and the expected properties of the cores and small-scale fragmentation inside of the clump. This science goal is for deuterated species to identify the densest, coldest cores and outflow tracers to measure any signature of star formation activity. A 7-point filled-hexagon mosaic is used to effeciently double the FOV (0.48 HPBW spacing) to cover the inner 1 pc of the clump, an area shown to have a high column density from a 70 um absorption feature. The clump has structure on th scale of 1' but we do not require the ACA because the science objective is to observe the embedded cores, and at 3.6 kpc a 0.1 pc core is 5.5", less than the 11.3" maximum angular scale of the 12m array. We choose the same spectral line sensitivity as the kinematic tuning. High deuteration fractions (0.3 - 0.5) require dense, cold gas, thus we expect the emission to be localized on scales less than or equal to the size of a core. The highly compact emission will favorably strengthen the line against the lower abundance. We select 0.3 km/s spectral resolution to span at least 3-4 channels across a > 1 km/s linewidth high-mass core. C32-1 configuration and ~1.6" resolution are used to span at least 3-4 resolution elements across a 0.1 pc (5.5") core and meet sensitivity goals. We observe the continuum with 4 GHz dedicated bandwidth in the kinematic tuning, thus this science goal is dedicated solely to high-spectral resolution line observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4029 -- Deuterated Tuning
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We observe deuterated species (N2D+, DCO+, DCN) as tracers of the coldest, densest cores and outflow tracers (CO, SiO) over the inner 1 pc of the pre-protocluster BGPSv2_G024.051-00.215 (BGPS catalog number 4029).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
(Note that this is the same wording as ScienceGoal "3151 -- Deuterated Tuning" but with subsituted quantities.)
We select parameters based on existing single-dish observations and the expected properties of the cores and small-scale fragmentation inside of the clump. This science goal is for deuterated species to identify the densest, coldest cores and outflow tracers to measure any signature of star formation activity. A 7-point filled-hexagon mosaic is used to effeciently double the FOV (0.48 HPBW spacing) to cover the inner 1 pc of the clump, an area shown to have a high column density from a 70 um absorption feature. The clump has structure on th scale of 1' but we do not require the ACA because the science objective is to observe the embedded cores, and at 3.6 kpc a 0.1 pc core is 4.5", less than the 11.3" maximum angular scale of the 12m array. We choose the same spectral line sensitivity as the kinematic tuning. High deuteration fractions (0.3 - 0.5) require dense, cold gas, thus we expect the emission to be localized on scales less than or equal to the size of a core. The highly compact emission will favorably strengthen the line against the lower abundance. We select 0.3 km/s spectral resolution to span at least 3-4 channels across a > 1 km/s linewidth high-mass core. C32-1 configuration and ~1.6" resolution are used to span at least 3-4 resolution elements across a 0.1 pc (4.5") core and meet sensitivity goals. We observe the continuum with 4 GHz dedicated bandwidth in the kinematic tuning, thus this science goal is dedicated solely to high-spectral resolution line observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the most massive Galactic pre-protocluster candidates discovered from the 1.1 mm Bolocam Galactic Plane Survey. As ideal targets for high-resolution observations to study the earliest phase of high-mass star-formation, we select clumps that are massive (Dust Mass > 800 Msun), cold (NH3 derived Kinetic Temperature ~ 12 K), nearby (Distance < 5 kpc), harbor dense gas (HCO+ Peak Intensity > 0.7 K), and show no evidence of star-formation activity from a diverse set of surveys. By simultaneously observing the molecular gas kinematics (HCO+, HCN, DCO+, N2D+, SiO, CO) and continuum sub-structure on scales $\lesssim 0.05$ pc, we shall measure the pre-protocluster fragmentation scale and identify intermediate and high-mass cores by comparing to the turbulent Jeans masses. By measuring the dynamical and virial states of the cores we shall be able to directly test the dominant mode of core mass accretion in either Turbulent Core Accretion or Competitive Accretion models.
